Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Expectation2: Provide emotional support and companionship to patients
Situation2: A patient has just received a difficult diagnosis and is visibly distressed and crying.
Story: I sit in the break room, my phone buzzing with another message from Alex. He’s barely slept since his brother died, and I know he needs me—he’s told me so, over and over. I want to be there, to hold him, to listen, to help him through the worst days of his life. But just as I start to type a reply, my pager goes off. Room 214. Mrs. Carter. She’s just been told her cancer is back, and when I walk in, she’s sobbing, clutching the thin hospital blanket. She looks up at me, eyes red and desperate, and I know she needs me too. My heart aches for both of them. I can’t be in two places at once, but both expect me to be their anchor. I feel the weight of their pain pressing in from all sides, and I don’t know how to choose who needs me more.
